title: Shri Uvl Radhakrishnan vs Central Vigilance Commission (Cvc) on 3 August, 2009
doc:
Shri Uvl Radhakrishnan vs Central Vigilance Commission (Cvc) on 3 August, 2009

                CENTRAL INFORMATION COMMISSION
                  Appeal No. CIC/WB/A/2008/00395 dated 27-2-2008
                    Right to Information Act 2005 - Section 19

Appellant:            Shri UVL Radhakrishnan,
Respondent:           Central Vigilance Commission (CVC)


                            Decision announced: 3.8.2009


FACTS

By an application of 25-10-2007 Shri UVL Radhakrishnan of Ernakulam, Kerala applied to the Central Vigilance Commission seeking the following information:

"I am in need of the following documents: -
1. CVC's 1st stage pertaining to (a) Shri Periasamy, (b) Shri Ashok Kumar, (c) Anbalgan, (d) M. Rajakumar and (e) U. V. L. Radhakrishnan.
2. Inasmuch as the departmental inquiry is completed for Shri Periasam, Shri Ashok Kumar and Shri Anbalagan, the CVC's 2nd stage advice pertaining to these three officers.
3. Inasmuch as the departmental inquiry is completed for Shri Periasamy, Shri Ashok Kumar and Shri Anbalagan, the copy of the inquiry proceedings and the copy of the Inquiry Officer's reports pertaining to these three officers.
4. Inasmuch as the CBI has recommended RDA against the above named five officers/ staff of Southern Railway, a copy of the CBI's report in this regard.
5. Copy of the correspondences between CBI and CVC relating to this case.
6. Copy of the correspondences between Southern Railway Admn. And CVC relating to this case.

I request you kindly to supply the certified/ authenticated copy of the information as mentioned in Para 4 above under section 6 of the Right to Information Act, 2005."

To this Shri UVL Radhakrishnan received a response dated 3-11-2007 from CPIO Shri Satvinder Singh, Under Secretary (Admn.) CVC as follows:

Para 4.1

2. CVC's 1st stage advice in the cited case contains names of other persons, in respect of whom disciplinary proceedings are still going on. hence the requested information is denied 1 under section 8 (1) (h) read with section 8 (1) (j) of the RTI Act. CIC's judgement in case No. CIC/AT/A/2006/00039 dated 1.1.2006 refers. Para 12 thereof states that "Premature disclosure of investigation related information has the potentiality to tar the employee's reputation, permanently, while cannot be undone even by his eventual exoneration. The balance of advantage thus, lies in exempting investigation/ enquiries in vigilance, misconduct or disciplinary cases etc. from disclosure requirements under the Act, till a decision in given case is reached by the competent authority. This also conforms to the letter and the spirit of section 8 (1) (h) of the RTI Act.

Para 4.2 to 4.5

3. Since disciplinary proceedings are contemplated/ pending against some officials, disclosure of information as requested by you would impede the process of logical conclusion of disciplinary proceedings. Therefore, the requested information is denied under section 8 (1) (h) &

(j) of the RTI Act.

Para 4.6

4. Normally Commission corresponds with Railway Board only."

Not satisfied, Shri Radhakrishnan moved an appeal before Shri V.K. Gupta, Addl. Secretary, CVC submitting as follows:

"The CPIO of CVC has miserably failed to take into consideration the orders of the Hon'ble Central Information Commission passed in the case of Shri Kathiresan vs. CBI (CIC/WB/A/2006/01033 dated 10.10.2007) had the CPIO of CVC taken some pains to such decisions of the CIC, he would not have refused to supply me the information sought for."

Upon this Shri Vineet K. Gupta, Addl. Secretary in an undated order has found as follows:

"I have perused the relevant record and I find that disciplinary proceedings in the case referred by you have not yet reached to its logical conclusion. I also notice that the Central information Commission in its decision dated 22.8.2007 in the case of 'V. R. Gokhale vs. Central Vigilance Commission' had held that section 8 (1) (h) covers not only investigation which would imply the enquiry process, but also apprehension and prosecution which will include orders of the final authority on the conclusion of the proceedings. In the light of the decision of the CIC in the aforementioned case, the action of the CPIO in denying information under section 8 (1) (h) of the RTI Act, appears justified.
2
The disclosure of information as requested by you at this stage would reveal the names of the officers dealing the case, stage of proceedings etc. The accused officers taking advantage of this information may influence the decision making process, which may also impede the process of disciplinary case to reach its logical conclusion. Accordingly, I uphold the decision of the CPIO denying you information under section 8 (1) (h) read with section 8 (1) (j) of the RTI Act."

Appellant Shri UVL Radhakrishnan's prayer before us in his second appeal is as below:

"a) set aside the letter No. CVC/RTI/07/615/71755 dated 3.11.2007 of the 1st Respondent;
b) set aside the letter No. CVC/RTI/APP/07/139/75364 dated Nil of the 2nd Respondent;
c) direct the Respondents herein to supply me all the information sought for by me vide my RTI Application dated 25.10.1997;
d) direct the Respondents to supply me the certified/ authenticated copies of the correspondences exchanged between the Railway Board and the CVC regarding the disciplinary proceedings against me."

The appeal was heard through videoconference on 3-8-2009. The following are present at CIC chambers.

Respondents Shri R.C. Arora, Dy. Secretary, CVC.

Shri S. K. Gwaliya, SO., CVC Although arrangements had been made for hearing through videoconference with Kochi, and appellant was informed of the date of hearing through our letter of 21-7-2009 appellant Shri Radhakrishnan opted not to be present. He has however sent written arguments on Internet together with a request that Thiru Venkataraman represent him through audio- conference. Upon calling Shri Venkataraman at 09444494573 however only the response 'outside the coverage area' was received.

Shri R.C. Arora, Dy. Secretary, CVC submitted that whereas CVC has indeed sent the first stage advice of the Commission to the Railway Board on 29-10-2003, it is for the Railway Board to now provide this advice to the accused as part of the charge-sheet. The second stage advice is only issued on receipt of an enquiry report. This advice has not yet been issued nor has 3 the CVC received the enquiry report. Shri R.C. Arora also placed before us a copy of the CBI report, which covers 130 pages together with attached documents. These are at the request of the CBI treated as confidential documents and not disclosed by CVC.

DECISION NOTICE On the basis of the above it is clear that question No.1 is to be answered not by the CVC but by the Railway Board. If the Railway Board has not yet supplied a copy of this advice to appellant Shri Radhakrishnan the reasons for the same will have to be obtained from the Railway Board. Since it is not the CVC, which is now conducting investigation that public authority cannot be asked to provide a document that has a bearing on that investigation, since, it is in no position to determine whether such disclosure would impede the process of investigation. On the other hand it would have been appropriate for the CVC to have transferred this question to the CPIO, Railway Board under sub Section (ii) of Section 6 (3). However it is clear that the investigation on which information has been sought involved a decidedly public activity.

Since there is no second stage advice given by the CVC it is clear that this cannot be provided to appellant Shri Radhakrishnan. Nevertheless, it was for the CVC to have informed the appellant that there was no such advise that could be provided by the CVC to him.

Insofar as the information requested regarding enquiry against three officers, these officers will constitute third parties in this case and information regarding them will clearly amount to invasion of privacy. We have no clear definition of what is meant by "invasion of privacy" within the RTI Act. We have no equivalent of UK's Date Protection Act, 1998, Sec 2 of which, titled 'Sensitive Personal Data', reads as follows:

"In this Act "sensitive personal data" means personal data consisting of information as to:
a) The racial or ethnic origin of the data subject. 
       b)     His political opinions.


                                         4
        c)     His religious beliefs or other beliefs of a similar nature.
       d)     Whether he is a member of a Trade Union.
       e)     His physical or mental health or condition.
       f)     His sexual life.
       g)     The commission or alleged commission by him of any
              offence.
       h)     Any proceedings for any offence committed or alleged to
have been committed by him, the disposal of such proceedings or the sentence of any court in such proceedings.

If we were to construe privacy to mean protection of personal data, this would be a suitable starting point to help define the concept. The US Restatement of the Law, Second, Torts, 652 on the other hand, defines the invasion of Privacy in the following manner:

One, who intentionally intrudes, physically or otherwise, upon the solitude or seclusion of another or his private affairs or concerns, is subject to liability to the other for invasion of his privacy, if the intrusion would be highly offensive to a reasonable person.
Moreover, the Supreme Court in Kharak Singh's case (AIR 1963 SC 1295) held that right to privacy is a guaranteed right under the Constitution of India. In Rajagopal v. State of Tamil Nadu, 1994(6) SCC 632 and in P.U.C.L. v. Union of India, (1997) ISCC 301 Supreme Court reiterated the law that right to privacy is part of the right to 'life' and 'personal liberty' enshrined under Article 21 of the Constitution. In these decisions, the Supreme Court placed reliance on the International Treaties to which India is signatory and came to a conclusion that Article 21 read with relevant Article in the International Treaty/Covenant would lead to a conclusion that right to privacy is part of Article 21.

The Supreme Court recognized that right to privacy by itself has not been identified under the Constitution and that as a concept; it may be too broad and moralistic to define it judicially. Whether the right to privacy can be claimed or has been infringed in a given case would depend on facts of each case. Describing the origin of the right to privacy. The Hon'ble Apex Court in Rajagopal's case cited above observed as follows: -

"The right to privacy as an independent and distinctive concept originated in the field to Tort Law, under which a new cause of 5 action for damages resulting from unlawful invasion of privacy was recognised. This right has two aspects which are but two faces of the same coin: (1) the General law of privacy which affords a tort action for damages resulting from an unlawful invasion of privacy and (2) the constitutional recognition given to the right to privacy which protects personal privacy against unlawful governmental invasion..... In recent times, however, this right has acquired a constitutional status."

The remaining three questions concern correspondence with the CBI, which as per the request of the CBI has been protected under the Official Secrets Act, 1923. Under Section 8 (2) of the RTI Act 2005 Notwithstanding anything in the Official Secrets Act, 1923 nor any of the exemptions permissible in accordance with sub- section (1), a public authority may allow access to information, if public interest in disclosure outweighs the harm to the protected interests.

It will, therefore, be open to the CBI to disclose such information and not for the CVC. For this reason this part of the request should have been transferred by CVC to the CBI under Sub Section (i) of Section 6 (3). In light of the above we hereby direct as follows:

i) Question No.1 is transferred to the CPIO, Railway Board for consideration under the RTI Act 2005 and for providing a response to appellant Shri Radhakrishnan within 15 working days of the date of receipt of this decision notice; in doing so he will bear in mind that the investigation on which information has been sought involves a decidedly public activity. It will be open to him however to take recourse to Sec 8 (1) (h)
ii) The response to question No.2 has been given in the discussion above. This in essence is that there is no information held by the CVC on the subject. No further action is therefore warranted
iii) Question Nos. 4 and 5 are transferred to the CPIO, CBI who will provide a response to appellant Shri Radhakrishnan after taking into account exemptions allowed under sub section (1) of Section 8 within 15 working days of the date of receipt of this decision notice;
6

This Appeal now stands disposed of. Announced in the hearing. Notice of this decision be given free of cost to the parties.

(Wajahat Habibullah) Chief Information Commissioner 3-8-2009 Authenticated true copy. Additional copies of orders shall be supplied against application and payment of the charges prescribed under the Act to the CPIO of this Commission.

(Pankaj K.P. Shreyaskar) Joint Registrar 3-8-2009 7
